title: Natural resources, Politics and Economic Development
abstractText:
Many observers have remarked that an abundance of valuable mineral resources, or a climate suitable for the growth of cash crops, often fail to lead to higher living standards, and in some cases positively appear to cause lower average incomes and higher rates of poverty.

 The possible existence of a natural resource curse is a puzzle: it is of course perfectly conceivable that a country will entirely squander its resource wealth, but this in itself does not mean that the country's population should be left worse off for it.

This project explores political determinants of the resource curse. It has two parts where two novel, complementary mechanisms contributing to the resource curse are modeled and evidence is gathered to test them. The hypothesised mechanisms revolve around competition for political control of the country, or power struggles. In the first mechanism an abundance of natural resources leads to ethnic conflict, and through it to slower or negative growth. In the second mechanism struggles over natural resources shorten the planning horizon of ruling elites, distorting their investment decisions.
